title: Tornadoes Rip Through Texas With Strong Storms Moving Eastward; Roughly 47,000 power customers in Texas and thousands more in Louisiana and Arkansas were experiencing outages as of Tuesday morning
text:
There were 21 tornadoes reported in Texas and one in Oklahoma Monday, according to preliminary National Weather Service data.

TV footage showed a high school in northern Texas with its roof torn off on Monday due to the storms. Footage from Rock Round, Texas, near Austin, showed people running for cover as powerful wind picked up debris in a Walmart parking lot, according to a video verified by Storyful, a social-media research company owned by News Corp, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal.

Video shared by the National Weather Service shows a tornado near Austin, Texas, destroying a mobile home and lifting debris across the area while causing significant damage to a single-family home.

Golf ball-sized hail and tornadoes are possible in parts of Mississippi, including in Jackson, the state's capital and most populous city, according to the National Weather Service.

"A deep surge of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico interacting with favorable dynamics both at the surface and aloft helped fuel widespread heavy rainfall and severe thunderstorms," the National Weather Service said.

Roughly 47,000 power customers in Texas, 12,000 customers in Louisiana and 10,000 customers in Arkansas were experiencing power outages as of Tuesday afternoon, according to outage tracker PowerOutage.us.

Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said many Texans' lives were disrupted, and that some have lost their homes.

"But it may be a miracle, also," he said in a press conference Monday. "Even though there's been some devastating physical damageâ€¦there is no report of loss of life."

Jana Houser, an associate professor at Ohio University who studies tornadoes and severe weather, said storms of this severity aren't unprecedented north of the Gulf of Mexico during the late winter and early spring.

Rainfall associated with the storm system will expand into the Midwest Tuesday, with some wintry precipitation possible in the northern Great Lakes region. The system is expected to move toward the Eastern U.S. Wednesday, although it will be less intense, and exit the East Coast on Thursday, according to the National Weather Service.

Write to Omar Abdel-Baqui at omar.abdel-baqui@wsj.com

Tornadoes Rip Through Texas With Strong Storms Moving Eastward
